 Let's say I'm walking on a road near an open field. I see a small insect crawling on the road and I realize that this could be really dangerous for the insect since someone might step on it.  Nor does it make the remotest glimmer of sense.
 
 Imagine you're walking to work, your usual route. You pass an old man with a beard holding a sign saying 'I command you not to walk on the cracks'. You shrug, walk on.
 
 Next day the old man's still there, looking even crosser. 'I SAID DON'T WALK ON THE CRACKS!'. Again you shrug it off.
 
 Third day, the old man's there with a gun. He levels it at you: 'What part of 'don't walk on the cracks' didn't you understand, dummie?'
 
 Then, just as you think he's going to plug you, he smiles. 'But hey, tell ya what, seeing as how I like you so much, I'll kill my kid instead. Jesus!' Up steps this young man: the old guy puts the gun to his head and shoots him dead.
 
 He beams. 'There! Now we're all square, and can start over.'
 
 Criminal insanity, or not?

 Brief quote: 
 
 
People talk confidently about scripture, but it is not clear that even the most ardent religious practitioners really know what it is. Protestant fundamentalists, for example, claim that they read the Bible in the same way as the early Christians, but their belief that it is literally true in every detail is a recent innovation, formulated for the first time in the late 19th century. Before the modern period, Jews, Christians and Muslims all relished highly allegorical interpretations of scripture. The word of God was infinite and could not be tied down to a single interpretation. Preoccupation with literal truth is a product of the scientific revolution, when reason achieved such spectacular results that mythology was no longer regarded as a valid path to knowledge.

 <flush<
 
 The Rabbis on Daniel
 
 Rabbi Judah, the main compiler of the Talmud said regarding the times referred to in Daniel's (Messianic) prophecy, "These times were over long ago." (Babylonian Talmud Sanhedrin.) 
 
 In the 12th Century AD, Rabbi Moses Ben Maimon (Maimonides), one of the most respected rabbis in history, and a man who rejected the messianic claim of Yeshua, stated:
 
 "Daniel has elucidated to us the knowledge of the end times. However, since they are secret, the wise [rabbis] have barred the calculation of the days of Messiah's coming so that the untutored populace will not be led astray when they see that the End Times have already come but there is no sign of the Messiah."
 
 Rabbi Moses Abraham Levi said, "I have examined and searched all the Holy Scriptures and have not found the time for the coming of Messiah clearly fixed, except in the words of Gabriel to the prophet Daniel, which are written in the 9th chapter of the prophecy of Daniel."

 The rules of salvation have never changed. That's a misconception. Justification / Righteousness has always been through faith in God (Genesis 15:6, for example), and through faith in Christ (who is God) - Ephesians 2:8-9. The law of Moses served 4 main purposes:
 
 1. It shows us the moral character of God.
 2. It was a guide for Godly living.
 3. It defined what sin was, so that the people would know their spiritual condition.
 4. By keeping the law to the degree people could, it helped them avoid the unpleasant consequences of breaking God's law (note Deuteronomy 28 - the "curses of disobedience").

That is, the idea that right and wrong are subjective is logically inconsistent. There cannot be a subjective "for me" right and wrong because then it is no longer right and wrong but rather an opinion. to say there are no absolute moral right or wrongs is clearly displayed in all of humanity as inconsistent. All of humanity has a concept of right or wrong.

 
 Indeed, all societies in history have had a sense of a dividing line between right and wrong, but that line has been moved back and forth in different societies. This effect is mainly due to an extreme ideology taking hold for whatever reason, and if it persists, the generation brought up under the new ideology (mostly) wholly absorb its values.
 
 Consider the most obvious example, those Nazis who willingly participated in the Holocaust. Granted, we have many examples of people who were sickened by what they did, and commited those crimes out of fear, but there were also a great many of them who believed it was the right thing to do; that killing Jews (and other non-Germans) was in fact morally acceptable. They believed this because they were brought up that way, and every conceivable nuance of Nazi German society was constructed to indoctrinate them in this belief.
 
 Another obvious example would be the terrorists who have been bombing Western targets in the last few years. These people do not do something they know to be wrong because they are insane or something, they believe it to be entirely morally appropriate for them to annihilate themselves and others in the name of a greater cause. 
 If we refine this example to the original mujahideen in Afghanistan, some of whom became the first footsoldiers of Bin Laden's extreme Islamist movement, we can see why they have this twisted sense of right and wrong. Most were young, born in the late 70s. Afganistan was invaded by the Soviets in 79 and has known nothing but violence since. Thus the children of the late 70s have known nothing but violence and Islam all their lives. This is what creates the "extreme Islamicist" state of mind that ordinary people cannot understand. They were then gathered by various ideologues and their anger and hatred directed, not without good argument, towards the Capitalist West.
 
 Other examples would be African (I do not mean to generalise here, but I do not know enough of the specifics) attitudes towards women, Muslim "honour killings" of women, the Japanese xenophobic culture pre-1945, and countless other examples from the past and present where people see a certain groups of people as almost "morally irrelevant", that it is not just "not wrong" but it is in fact right that we keep women/other races/whoever in their place, and if this is to be achieved by killing them, so be it.
 
 The fact that so many different moral strucures have existed throughout history leads me to question your proposition that
 
You have a sense of right and wrong, it exists inherent in your being. Therefore, there must be an objective right and wrong. If so, it cannot come from humans.

 Yes, I have a sense of right and wrong, but it is not inherent in my being, it is taught to me from the day I am born by my parents and by the society and environment in which I live.
 Therefore, if moral outlooks are dictated by environment, there is no objective right and wrong. If there were, it would of course not come from humans. 
 However, I believe that the historical records show quite plainly that morality is an entirely human construct, which has been changed again and again over time to either:
 1)Suit the goals of a power base, or 
 2)Justify the irreconcilable emotions of a people who have suffered a catastrophe.
 Your assertion that 
 
 every human on the planet has the same sense of right and wrong

 is clearly not well supported.

You are correct, as I based my argument strictly on the single individual, however, it would take very little to show that every human on the planet has the same sense of right and wrong. .... All of humanity has a concept of right or wrong. It is very very easy to show. The existence of laws is one way. They are everywhere, in every society, even in the tribal. To say that humanity set up the concept is inconsistent. That would mean that somewhere at sometime, there was a a time and place where right and wrong did not exist.

 
 The concept of right and wrong is a cultural universal, certainly, and like you I would never argue for its being a human construct (in the sense that some people somewhere sat down and invented it).
 
 Rather, it is intrinsic to the way human brains work. Kohler's work on the development of moral behaviour in children shows a very predictable pattern of rule acquisition, analogous to the predictable acquisition of language: seeking rules to govern behaviour is 'hard-wired' (or, to use your phrase, 'it exists inherent in your being').
 
 Where we will differ, I suspect, is over its origin. From my perspective, it is an evolved trait, strongly favoured by natural selection: no supernatural agency required.
 
 Like Liminus in the preceding post, I will take issue with
 
 
every human on the planet has the same sense of right and wrong.

 
 This is demonstrably untrue. In many tribal societies, killing people outside the tribe is not regarded as a moral offence. The Aztecs waged war on neighbouring peoples specifically to capture victims for sacrifice, and regarded that as a perfectly proper thing to do. The Old Testament writes approvingly of infanticide in numerous places.
 
 People are born with a strong drive to acquire, in infancy, a sense of right and wrong, as they are to acquire a language. But just as they are not programmed to acquire a particular language, so the social environment they grow up in can inculcate a very flexible sense of what is acceptable behaviour and what is not. A culture's morality evolves to maximise that culture's fitness: there are no absolutes.

The idea that Jesus would conform to modern day social liberalism is absurd. It's a view that takes Jesus out of the context he was in and tries to impose a modern-day context on him.
 
 The views of the Pharisees of Jesus' day are not early versions of modern conservatives. 
 
 The last time I checked, Jesus never pushed for socialism, never burned the Roman flag in the streets, never protested Jewish or Roman war engagements, never organized or participated in gay pride events, never pushed to legalize abortion, and he never passed out a single condom. (Yeah, I know, they probably didn't have condoms, but surely you get my point.)
 The bottom line is that the cultural differences are so much between our culture and theirs, that claiming Jesus was liberal or conservative in any way doesn't even work. Jesus made it clear He was the only way to God. Not exactly the social liberal ideal of diversity and tolerance.
 
 Jesus' view on women (which was more tolerant than his peers) are really no more compatible with the modern social liberals' ideals than the modern conservative.
 
 Everyone always likes to make Jesus into their own image, instead of really reading him with an open mind and finding out what He was really like. The liberals here are just as guilty of that as anyone.

 Really?
 
 
every human on the planet has the same sense of right and wrong.

 
 I see the ambiguity here, but to me that reads as '...the same sense of what is right and wrong'. However, I am happy to be corrected.
 
 
The evolutionary concept simply doesn't hold water logically. If it were an evolutional issue then we would see different traits evolving. Knowing right and wrong is existent in every person. If it was simply a trait that evolved like, say a placenta versus egg laying(as evolutionists say, I disagree with evolution but that is another argument and I can accept it for the sake of this argument), then what are the trait counterparts to knowing "right and wrong".

 
 With respect, I think you're confused here. The argument was that brains are built with a 'rule-acquiring' program as part of their operating system, analogous to their 'language acquiring' program. 'Knowing right and wrong is existent in every person', certainly - just as language is, and, by my argument, for the same reason.
 
 You raise what you call two 'traits', placenta versus egg laying, and ask 'what are the trait counterparts to knowing "right and wrong?". Having a placenta and laying cleidoic eggs are traits characterising different classes of vertebrate, not genetic variants within a species like blue and brown eyes. Just as all (eutherian) mammals reproduce with a placenta, so all human brains develop the right/wrong program.
 
 In cases of severe mental handicap, of course, it may be that neither language nor a sense of right and wrong develop. This, after all, is why civilised societies exempt the mentally handicapped from criminal responsibility.
 
 
If it were indeed evolutionary, we would see whole societies isolated from us that would never demonstrate any knowledge of the existence of right and wrong.

 
 Not so. All extant human societies are very closely related: there is no more reason why we should expect to see contemporary societies devoid of a moral sense than there is to see societies devoid of language.
 
 
To say that they have been killed off in survival of the fittest, you would have to show me that society in the fossil record. And you will unllikely be able to show that their "right and wrong" did not exist whereas ours do.

 
 I'd be interested in your notion of what fossilised morality would look like. We cannot know where in hominid history something akin to what we would call morality emerged, but I would be confident that it was fully installed in the behaviour of the earliest Homo sapiens. To ask me to show you a fossilised human society (!) with no sense of right and wrong is a gigantic red herring.
 
 Cordially,
 
 JH

 That's an interesting point. Providing appropriate rites of passage has always been one of religion's main functions, and even in a secular society some people still find religious rites more satisfying than their secular alternatives. Even so,
 
 
In 1971 the proportion of English weddings that were religious was 60 percent. This declined fairly steadily to 31 percent in 2000.
 
 Steve Bruce, Sociology of Religion Summer 2001

 
 I suspect the decline will continue. Secular funerals will remain rarer for a longer time: unless the deceased has willed a non-religious send-off, a religious ceremony is still the default option.

 Here's an interesting article on Christianity in early America:
 
 Library of Congress on Christianity  
 
 http://lcweb.loc.gov/exhibits/religion/rel02.html
 
 It dispells the notion about deism being prevalent at that time, i.e.
 
 Another religious movement that was the antithesis of evangelicalism made its appearance in the eighteenth century. Deism, which emphasized morality and rejected the orthodox Christian view of the divinity of Christ, found advocates among upper-class Americans. Conspicuous among them were Thomas Jefferson and John Adams. Deists, never more than "a minority within a minority," were submerged by evangelicalism in the nineteenth century.

Yes please. God will judge each on thier merits, how they lived their lives. How "good" they were. It would also spare me your shrill histronics
 
 
 How are we saved? Ephesians 2:8 For it is by grace through faith in Jesus christ that you have been saved, and this not from yourselves, it is the gift of God- 9 not by works, so that no one can boast. 10 For we are God's workmanship, created in Christ Jesus to do good works, which God prepared in advance for us to do.
 
 "I am the way and the truth and the life. No man comes to the father except through me."  John 14:6
 
 Acts 4:10-12 says: "Be it known unto you all, and to all the people of Israel, that by the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth, whom ye crucified, whom God raised from the dead, even by him doth this man stand here before you whole. This is the stone which was set at nought of you builders, which is become the head of the corner. Neither is there salvation in any other: for there is none other name under heaven given among men, whereby we must be saved.  
 
 Jesus is not just a good way to heaven; He's the only way to heaven. 
 
 God will judge each man's works to determine their rewards, not their salvation (I Corinthians 3:11-15). Salvation is only through grace through faith in Christ.
 
 Also recommend you read Romans chapters 3 and 4.
